title: A Cup of Tea or Coffee a day and dementia risk: What Sri Lankans need to know
byline: In Sri Lanka, tea and coffee are not lifestyle accessories. They are part of who we are. The first cup at dawn steadies the morning. The mid-afternoon brew carries conversations across office tables and village verandas.

title: IMF Managing Director to visit Sri Lanka from February 16 to 18
byline: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva will visit Sri Lanka from February 16 to 18, 2026, a spokesperson said.

title: BASL to address legal community crisis after Akuregoda shooting, calls emergency meeting
byline: The Bar Association of Sri Lanka has called an emergency general meeting of all its members tomorrow (15), the first such gathering in 14 years, in response to growing concern within the legal community over security and the rule of law.

title: Youth used during Aragalaya, leaders became “kings” – Namal
byline: National Organizer and MP of the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna, Namal Rajapaksa said that some people who encouraged public protests later gained power, while a group of young people who joined the Aragalaya lost their lives.

title: Rolls-Royce Cullinan arrives for Rathna Sahal and owner
byline: Rice-mill owner-turned-businessman Mithrapala Lankeshwara said that a luxury Rolls-Royce vehicle he imported is scheduled to be cleared from Customs today.

title: President to attend India–AI Impact Summit 2026 in New Delhi
byline: President Anura Kumara Dissanayake will attend the India–AI Impact Summit 2026, which will be hosted by the Government of India in New Delhi from February 16 to 20, 2026.

title: Sajith proposes National Reconciliation Council headed by President
byline: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa proposed the establishment of a National Reconciliation Council headed by the President.

title: Indian team arrives ahead of Pakistan match on Sunday
byline: The India national cricket team arrived in Sri Lanka ahead of their much-anticipated match against the Pakistan national cricket team scheduled for Sunday.

title: Sri Lanka’s strategic location offers it outsized importance: top U.S. official
byline: U.S. Assistant Secretary for South and Central Asia Paul Kapur, a key official of the Trump administration, said Sri Lanka’s strategic location offered outsized importance and can make it a target for coercion.

title: Ports advised to cut container rehandles before betting on mega projects
byline: The global port optimisation experts are cautioning the Sri Lankan terminal operators against prioritising massive infrastructure investments without first addressing the underlying operational inefficiencies, warning that capacity expansion is not the immediate answer for growth.

title: A Cup of Tea or Coffee a Day and the Risk of Dementia: What Sri Lankans need to know
byline: In Sri Lanka, tea and coffee are not lifestyle accessories. They are part of who we are. The first cup at dawn steadies the morning. The mid-afternoon brew carries conversations across office tables and village verandas.

title: Namal calls for Presidential Commission on Aragalaya funds
byline: Namal Rajapaksa said a Presidential Commission should be appointed to investigate the recent Aragalaya and the foreign funds received to support it.

title: SriLankan Airlines share issue planned with vested interests: Opposition MP
byline: A share issue has been planned for the national carrier SriLankan Airlines, and it is  being planned to help certain companies to buy it over, an Opposition MP alleged today.

title: Valentine’s Day: What Sri Lankans Should Know About Its History and Celebration
byline: Understanding the history of Valentine’s Day helps separate fact from legend and explains how February 14 evolved into a global celebration of love.

title: Music, Helmets, Knives, and Bottles Banned at India–Pakistan Match
byline: Police in Colombo have decided to enforce a zero-tolerance policy on prohibited items that will include musical instruments, helmets, jackets, glass bottles, large travel bags, alcoholic beverages, knives, sharp objects, drones and

title: Trump says Iran regime change is ’best thing that could happen’
byline: US President Donald Trump says regime change in Iran is ’’the best thing that could happen’’, signifying one of his clearest endorsements for replacing the clerical establishment.

title: Husband released from remand allegedly kills wife, sets house on fire
byline: A man strangled his wife to death and set their house on fire yesterday morning.

title: Police seek dash cam video to identify Akuregoda double shooting suspects
byline: The Sri Lanka Police have sought public assistance to identify the suspects involved in the fatal double shooting that took place in Akuregoda yesterday.

title: Advisory issued for severe lightning in several provinces
byline: The Department of Meteorology has issued an ‘Amber’ advisory warning of severe lightning in the Western, Sabaragamuwa and Southern Provinces, as well as in the Badulla and Nuwara Eliya districts.

title: Tucker 94 fires Ireland to 235 against Oman at T20 World Cup
byline: Captain Lorcan Tucker struck an unbeaten 94 to power Ireland to a mammoth 235-5 against Oman on Saturday, the highest total so far in this year’s T20 World Cup.

title: CEB seeks 13.56% electricity tariff hike for April–June period
byline: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) has submitted a proposal to the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) seeking a 13.56 percent increase in electricity tariffs for the second quarter of this year.

title: Navy seizes over 50kg of Hashish in Mannar operation
byline: The Sri Lanka Navy conducted a special operation in the southern sea area off Mannar today (14), resulting in the arrest of two suspects and the seizure of a dinghy carrying two suspicious sacks contained more than 50 kilograms of hashish.

title: T20 World Cup: England keep Super 8 hopes alive
byline: England kept their Super 8 hopes alive with a hard-fought five-wicket victory over Scotland in Match 23 of the ICC Men’s T20 World Cup.

title: England bowl Scotland out for 152 in T20 World Cup
byline: England’s bowlers got their mojo back and vindicated Harry Brook’s decision to field by dismissing Scotland for 152 in the T20 World Cup in Kolkata on Saturday.

title: Boycott Drama Over: India–Pakistan T20 World Cup Clash back on in Colombo
byline: Cricket’s fiercest rivalry is back as India and Pakistan gear up to clash in Colombo on Sunday, February 15. Pakistan had briefly threatened to boycott the match, citing solidarity with Bangladesh, but the threat was resolved after last-minute ICC negotiations. Broadcasters, wary of lost ad revenue, also pushed to ensure the marquee fixture went ahead. It remains uncertain whether rain might affect play.
